sections.content:
The **webpm-client** library provides a powerful and flexible way to manage and install components in both the main
thread and Web Workers.

*  The primary entry point is  <mkapi-api-link nav="@nav/api/MainModule" semantic="module"> MainModule</mkapi-api-link> , which serves as the core module for installing components in the main 
   thread.

*  The  <mkapi-api-link nav="@nav/api/WorkersPoolModule" semantic="module"> WorkersPoolModule</mkapi-api-link>  extends functionality by enabling component installation in Web Workers, as well as 
  task execution and monitoring.

*  The  <mkapi-api-link nav="@nav/api/ViewsModule" semantic="module"> ViewsModule</mkapi-api-link>  provides components to visualize the installed resources or to track the progress of their 
   installation.


Use this documentation to explore the available modules, APIs, and best practices for integrating **webpm-client** 
into your project.

The main module of this library is responsible for resource installation within the main thread of the browser,
using the  function.

This module provides UI components for visualizing installed resources and tracking real-time
installation progress.

<note level="warning">
This module is **not included by default** in the main library.
It must be explicitly installed using .
</note>


Key components include:
- : A convenient wrapper around  that integrates a visual progress
  indicator.
- : Displays a snapshot of currently installed resources.
- : Provides a dynamic visualization of a .

Additionally, this module offers components for building **custom views**, allowing tailored
monitoring and interaction with installed resources.

Add-on module enhancing [Web Workers](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Web_Workers_API/Using_web_workers)
management by automating environment setup, handling task scheduling, and managing resources efficiently.

<note level="warning">
This module is **not included by default** in the main library.
Consumers must install it explicitly using .
</note>

The main entry point of the module is .
